content.p: Suppose a ladder of length {{ladderlength}} ft is leaning against a wall. Then the base of the ladder is pulled away from the wall at a rate of {{velocityx}} feet/second. What is the velocity of the top of the ladder when the base of the ladder is {{distancex}} feet away from the wall?

Suppose an oil spill in the ocean formed a circle and was growing at a rate of {{dadt}} feet^2/minute. When the oil slick reaches a radius of {{radius}}, how fast is the radius of the oil spill growing?

Suppose a person who was {{heightperson}} feet tall was standing between a light on the ground and a wall. Initially, they are {{disttolight}} feet away from the light and {{disttowall}} feet away from the wall. If they start walking torwards the {{persondirection}} at a speed of {{personspeed}} feet/second, how fast would the height of the shadow they cast be changing (at the initial instant they begin walking) and in what direction?

Suppose that a television camera is filming a rocket and that the camera is located on the ground {{X}} miles from the launchpad. The camera must remain locked onto the rocket in the center of its shot, and therefore, the angle of elevation for the camera's line-of-sight must increase as the rocket travels. If the speed of the rocket is {{dhdt}} miles per second, how fast is the angle of elevation for the camera's line-of-sight increasing when the rocket's height is {{h}} miles. Give your answer in degrees per second and round to 3 decimal places.
